annotations: 2 DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSIS
2.1 Primary headaches
2.1.1 Tension headaches
Tension-type headaches3,4 are a heterogeneous entity, encompassing conditions of widely differing severity and impact, although usually not severe.
They account for almost two-thirds of all primary headaches, and can present in episodic or chronic form (headaches lasting at least 15 days/month and for more than 6 months).
Typically, the pain involves the forehead, pericranial and occipital muscles, and is accompanied by tension in the paracervical and trapezius muscles.
Muscle tension in these muscles is frequently observed. There are many triggers.
Physical and psychological stress, as well as meteorological factors, feature prominently at all stages of life.
2.1.2 Migraine
Migraine5,6 accounts for around 15% of primary headache disorders.
It affects 15% of the population, more frequently women than men (ratio 3/1).
Prevalence is 25% in women aged 40.
The majority (80%) of migraine sufferers present their first attacks before the age of 30.
The frequency of attacks is highly variable, classically decreasing with age, and pregnancy induces transient remission in 70% of cases.
Migraine is subdivided into three clinical entities:
Migraine without aura (formerly known as migraine commune): represents the majority of migraine attacks.

Migraine with aura (formerly accompanied migraine): around 15-20% of migraine sufferers experience transient focal neurological symptoms such as visual, sensory, motor or language disturbances, referred to as "aura" because they often occur before the headache.
These phenomena of irritation and/or neurological deficit are reversible and have the particularity of setting in and regressing within a few minutes rather than abruptly.
A distinction is made between migraine with typical aura and basilar migraine (characterized by transient visual tr., vertigo, tinnitus, ataxia)9 .
Migraine complications: migraine status, transformation into chronic migraine (often related to excessive medication) and migraine infarction are the most frequent complications.
2.1.3 Primary neuralgia
Damage to any cranial nerve innervating the structures of the face can cause neuralgia.
This is characterized by painful attacks of stereotyped localization, which are very violent, short (fractions of a second), recurrent and throbbing.

In the case of neuralgia, it is essential to differentiate between secondary causes (e.g. inflammation due to multiple sclerosis or borreliosis, or tumour compression or infiltration) and the primary (idiopathic) form.
In the case of secondary neuralgia, pain sometimes persists between attacks.

The main types of neuralgia are: 1) Trigeminal neuralgia (electrical discharges in the territory of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve, often triggered by a "trigger" zone or by chewing or brushing teeth).
Trigeminal neuralgia is the most common facial neuralgia, preferentially affecting women over the age of 40 (annual incidence of 3-13/100,000 individuals, up to 30/100,000 in the 70+ age group).
Before the age of 40, its appearance is a warning sign that a secondary cause is being sought (see above).
2) Glossopharyngeal neuralgia (same characteristics as trigeminal neuralgia, except that the pain is located in the pharynx, radiates to the ear and is triggered by swallowing).
3) Arnold's neuralgia (neuralgic-type pain in the territory of the suboccipital nerve, triggered by palpation of its emergence).
2.1.4 Cluster headache
It accounts for < 1% of primary headaches and affects around six men for every woman.
More often episodic, cluster headache can also present in a chronic form, defined as persisting for more than a year without more than 14 consecutive days of respite.
Cluster headache is usually unilateral, orbito-temporal and of limited duration (between 15 minutes and 3 hours).
It is often associated with local neurovegetative symptoms (lacrimation, rhinorrhea).
2.1.5 Chronic paroxysmal hemicrania
This is a headache similar to cluster headache, which mainly affects women (shorter duration of symptoms than cluster headache, but higher frequency) and responds specifically to indomethacin.

indomethacin (therapeutic test: indomethacin 3x25 mg/d for 48 h, followed by 3x50 mg/d in case of no or insufficient response, which can be further increased in case of partial response; then treat with the lowest possible maintenance dose).
